column1: Guaymas (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈɡwajmas]) is a city in Guaymas Municipality
column2: in the southwest part of the state of Sonora
column3: in northwestern Mexico. The city is 134 km south of the state capital of Hermosillo
column4: and 389 kilometres (242 mi) from the U.S. border. The municipality is located on the Gulf of California and the western edge of the Sonoran Desert and has a hot
column5: dry climate and 117 km of beaches. The municipality's formal name is Guaymas de Zaragoza and the city's formal name is the Heróica Ciudad de Guaymas.The city proper is mostly an industrial port and is the principal port for the state of Sonora. The city has a well-attended annual carnival
column6: which has been held since 1888. Nearby
column7: San Carlos and its beaches are major tourist attractions.

column1: == History ==
Before the arrival of the Europeans
column2: the areas now known as Guaymas was dominated by the Guaymas
column4: two Spanish ships
column5: the Santa Agueda and El Trinidad
column6: arrived in Guaymas Bay. They were commanded by Francisco de Ulloa
column7: who called the area "the port of ports."Some small Jesuit missions in the area were founded in the 1610s and 1620s
column8: when Jesuits founded eight mission villages with the Yaqui.  The Seri strongly opposed the settlement of Europeans and resisted fiercely until 1769.Juan María de Salvatierra and Eusebio Kino asked for permission to evangelize the area
column10: Salvatierra came to this area and established the Loreto mission somewhat inland from where Guaymas is now. To receive supplies by ship and evangelize the Guaymas Indians
column11: the Jesuits founded another small mission on the bay
column12: which they called San José de Guaymas. It was headed by Manuel Diaz. The Seri repeatedly attacked the San José mission
column13: forcing it to be abandoned and rebuilt several times. The last time this mission was abandoned was in 1759.In 1767
column14: Viceroy Marqués de Croix ordered a major military offensive
column16: to subdue the Seri and Pima tribes. After doing so
column17: the Spanish colonials built an adobe fort with four towers in Guaymas
column18: initially under the command of Captain Lorenzo Cancio. No traces of the fort remain today
column19: but the San José mission is marked by a church located on the road leading to Empalme. Around the same time
column20: the colonists formally mapped the Guaymas Bay and officially founded the city of Guaymas in 1769 by José Gálvez in Real de Alamos on behalf of the viceregal government. Despite the decree
column21: no colonists settled there until the early 19th century.In the late 18th and early 19th century
column22: there was supposedly only one inhabitant in Guaymas
column24: who was said to be a drunk and a thief. At the beginning of the 19th century
column25: the village began to be populated by farmers and ranchers
column26: who held large properties but did not have markets for their products. Farming was on a subsistence level. In 1811
column28: and customs were established later in 1823. Guaymas received the name San Fernando de Guaymas in 1820. Ships visited the bay intermittently but only one house was here for customs purposes. In this era
column29: it was safer to travel by sea than by land;  Guaymas became an important stopping point for those heading north or south. The first commercial imports came through here in 1827. With the population of the area by European-Mexicans
column30: the Guaymas moved to a town called Belén. They eventually disappeared as a distinct group.The port became a municipality in 1825. During the Mexican–American War
column31: American warships such as the Portsmouth
column33: the Dale and the Argos anchored here near the Pajaros Island and the Almagre Grande. The ships fired on the town and captured it
column34: keeping it in U.S. hands from 1847 to 1848.In the mid-19th century
column35: Guaymas was the target of several filibusters
column36: or unauthorized military expeditions from foreign nations
column37: designed to foment rebellion. One was done by the crew of the English sailing vessel “Challenge” and a French ship named La Belle commanded by Count Gastón Raousett-Boulbón
column38: who intended to take over all of Sonora. The French attacked the city on 13 July 1854
column39: but the port was successfully defended by José María Yáñez. A firing squad executed the count soon afterwards. The national government elevated the town to city status as a reward for this action in 1859. Later
column41: it gave Guaymas the title of “heroic city” for the same action. The municipality's formal name of Guaymas de Zaragoza was authorized in 1862. In 1865
column42: French ships arrived to attack Republican forces
column43: which were forced to retreat. The French occupied the city until 1866.By 1890
column45: 000 residents and was somewhat prosperous. The Carnival tradition it established then continues to this day.On October 4–5
column47: Guaymas was struck by major hurricane and accompanying storm surge which killed some 500 people in the city and environs.During the Mexican Revolution
column48: the first ever aerial bombardment of a naval target occurred just off the coast of Guaymas: in 1913
column49: five military ships belonging to Federal forces appeared in the bay
column50: and General Alvaro Obregon of the rebel army ordered the bombing of these ships using the aircraft “Sonora.”The first modern port facilities were built in 1925 for the Mexican navy.  In 1942 a commercial pier and warehouse were built at La Ardilla. Guaymas’ importance as a port grew in the 1950s
column52: a pier for the national oil company PEMEX was built. A naval ship repair station
column54: and silos for the export of grain
column55: called the Almacenes Nacional de Depósito

column2: Baja California Sur was established in 1972. In the 1980s

column5: Cementos Tolteca and Compañía Mexicana de Ácido Sulfúrico. Due to changes in Mexican maritime law

column1: == Climate ==
Guaymas has a desert climate (Köppen climate classification BWh)
column2: with hot summers and warm winters.

column1: == The city ==
Guaymas is basically an industrial and shrimp-fishing port which has conserved a number of historical attractions. Buildings in the historic center have a mix of Neoclassical and Moorish facades
column2: however many are in disrepair. The city has two main plazas
column4: which is nicknamed the “plaza de los flojos” (lazy men's plaza) for the large number of people who relax there. In the 13 de Julio Plaza there is a monument commemorating the defense of Guaymas by General José María Yáñez against a French incursion in 1854. The most famous person in this plaza is León Riso
column5: who has spent fifty-five years here selling homemade ice cream. The Moorish style kiosk in the center has deteriorated due to the humidity. The town's main church
column8: faces this plaza.The other major plaza is the Plaza de los Tres Presidentes with statues of Plutarco Elías Calles
column9: Adolfo de la Huerta and Abelardo L. Rodríguez all of whom are from near Guaymas. Facing this plaza is the Municipal Palace and a small concrete pier with the Statue of the Fisherman
column10: on which is the lyrics of the song “La Barca de Guaymas.” This statue is considered to be emblematic to the city.Other landmarks include the old Bank of Sonora building with its Neoclassical facade
column12: the Casa de las Conchas (House of Shells)
column13: which has a large collection on display and for sale
column14: and the Casa de Cultura (Cultural Center)
column15: which offers classes and workshops in various arts.Institutes of higher education in the city include the Instituto Tecnológico de Guaymas [1]
column17: Guaymas [2] and the Universidad TecMilenio Guaymas [3]

column1: Baseball is a popular sport in this city. The local professional team is called the Ostioneros.[4]
The city has ferry service to Santa Rosalía
column2: B.C. and an international airport.

column1: == Carnival of Guaymas ==
Guaymas holds one of Mexico's major Carnival celebrations
column2: and is one of the oldest in the country. The annual event begins on the Thursday before Ash Wednesday and ends at the stroke of midnight of the beginning of Lent. Events are held in several locations with a number of events
column4: extending over multiple days. It begins with the Quema del malhumor or Hoguera
column5: when an effigy of something or someone who has displeased the public is burned. Each year
column6: the effigy represents something different. In past years
column7: the effigy has represented the figures of Carlos Salinas de Gortari
column10: Mexico's value added tax and lack of water. In 2009
column11: the effigy was of singer Julio Preciado for his poor interpretation of Mexico's national anthem at the recent Serie del Caribe baseball tournament.  Other major events include concerts by regionally and nationally known artists
column12: a multi-day parade with floats and the election of the King and Queen of the Carnival.The history of Carnival in Guaymas begins after the Reform War and French Intervention in Mexico
column13: when Guaymas and the rest of the country experienced a period of peace and economic development. The success of Guaymas’ port attracted a number of European immigrants and visitors. They brought the idea of organizing a Carnival similar to those celebrated in Europe. Guaymas’ first carnival is recorded in book called El Viejo Guaymas (Old Guaymas) written by Alfonso Iberri. It was one of the first to take place in Mexico. In 1888
column14: the first Carnival Queen was María Zuber and the first King was Alfredo Díaz Velasco. The King and Queen were paraded on the streets of Guaymas in a coach
column15: followed by coaches carrying their entourage. The event ended with a grand ball that night.Initially
column16: the Carnival event was restricted to the upper classes. The lower classes watched the annual parade
column17: but the most important events were the balls given at various mansions. This tradition continued until the Mexican Revolution. In 1913
column18: Alvaro Obregon took control of the port
column19: and the war devastated the area economically. Many of the businesspeople had sided with Porfirio Díaz and had to leave. The city wanted to keep the annual Carnival tradition. Various social clubs vied for control over the event
column20: especially the naming of the Carnival Queen. The queen was determined by which group provided the most money for Carnival events
column21: which led to widespread cheating and scandals
column23: when the military had to get involved to keep order.The goal of the fundraising was to decorate the 13 de Julio Plaza
column24: as the event had become public. People came to the plaza dressed in costumes
column25: and the event drew people from neighboring cities. The event still had the yearly parades
column27: and both private and public balls. Masks hiding identity were permitted
column28: allow for the playing of practical jokes
column29: and homosexuals were among those who took advantage of the anonymity.By the 1960s and 1970s
column30: the Carnival had evolved into an entirely popular event with mass participation
column31: bringing in many visitors to the city. Sister cities such as El Segundo
column33: Arizona were invited to participate. After the inauguration of the Plaza de los Tres Presidentes
column34: the event was moved to this larger plaza
column35: which allowed for carnival rides and concerts by regionally and nationally known artists. The use of masks was banned due to violence. The traditional queen is now popularly elected
column36: and the King is named the Rey Feo (Ugly King). Over time
column37: the new plaza was no longer large enough to hold the event
column38: and an admission charge was instituted. Security was instituted as well as checkpoints for weapons. The coronation of a Gay King was begun
column39: and the number of floats participating in the parade grew.

column1: == Tracking station ==
The Guaymas-Empalme station for space observations is about 10 km (6 mi) east of Empalme
column2: Sonora
column3: adjacent to Mexican Federal Highway No. 15.  It is operated by the Mexican Space Agency.  As a major link in the NASA's worldwide Manned Space Flight Network
column4: the Guaymas Tracking Station
column6: played a key role in tracking American manned space flights in the Mercury
column8: and Apollo programs through Apollo 13.  The U.S. discontinued its use on November 30
column9: 1970 due to changes in the Apollo mission profile which no longer required the Guaymas station. Equipment designed especially for support of the Apollo program was removed
column10: but other equipment was left for support of Mexican space activities and future programs of mutual interest to Mexican scientists and NASA.

column1: According to local sources the station was abandoned shortly after the conclusion of the Apollo program and has been used recently as a warehouse for agricultural stores.
